title: CJK = [C(t) + C(s)] + J +K ... or, is there is a problem in east asia
content:
Recently I was working on a project for a client, and realised that they used different fonts for their East Asian markets. I was looking in proposing one gothic CJK font for the whole region, but had to realise that that'snot so easy.

I know there are Mircosoft fontswhich offer a complete CJK set, but looking for fonts with a good variety of weights, to mach them with the latin house-type, was not easy at all.

For the time we kept the 3 different fonts for C, J & K.

Did anyone else have the same problem?

j.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141103114347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/cjk_5023.jpg)
author: hartmannsgruber

comments.content:
What you're after is a Pan-CJK font, meaning a single typeface design that serves multiple CJK locales. This is a topic of one of my IUC33 presentations that will take place in about two weeks. See: [IUC33](http://web.archive.org/web/20141103114347/http:/www.unicodeconference.org/conference-at-a-glance.htm)

The primary issue is that some CJK Unified Ideographs may require two or more glyphs to satisfy the CJK locales, due to Han Unification.

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)

Ken,

I checked out the link. A very interesting conference indeed. But unfortunately I will not be able to come to San Jose.

It looks like there is no easy fix to my problem.

I wonder how designers in the region deal with it? Are there foundries of fonts (i guess 4 localised versions) that match up?

---  
JH, London

The iPhone includes two Pan-CJK fonts. They went with the TTC approach, meaning that four separate font instances, one for each of the CJK locales (Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, Japanese, and Korean), are advertised. Send to me an email in a couple of weeks, after IUC33 is over, and I'll send to you my presentation about this topic. It will details the issues, the work involved, and various solutions.

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)

Thanks Ken. Will e-mail you then.  
Would love to see your presentation.

best.
